talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Repatriation, upon notice -

quote.para: Will he furnish the following information with respect to the filling of vacancies upon the War Pensions Entitlement and Assessment Appeal Tribunals: - (a) Are applications invited from any interested persons who considers himself qualified for the position or are applications restricted to nominations from ex-servicemen's organizations; (b) by whom, and by what procedure, are the applications dealt with; and (c) upon whom does the Minister rely for a recommendation as to the most suitable person offering?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Repatriation has supplied the following information: -

quote.para: Section 55 of the Repatriation Act 1920- 1953 reads-
55. - (1.) There shall be such War Pen sions Entitlement Tribunals as are established by the Governor-General.
(2.) An Appeal Tribunal shall consist of a Chairman and two other members all of whom shall be appointed by the Governor-General.
(3.) The Chairman of an Appeal Tribunal shall be a person who has been admitted to practise as a barrister or solicitor of the High Court or of the Supreme Court of a State.

(4.) The members other than the Chairman shall be returned soldiers, and one shall be selected for appointment from a list containing the names of not less than three returned soldiers, submitted to the Minister by any organization representing returned soldiers throughout the Commonwealth.
Sub-sections (2.) and (3.) of section 65 of the Repatriation Act 1920-1953 read -

(2.) Each Assessment Appeal Tribunal shall consist of a Chairman appointed by the Minister and of two other members who shall be medical practitioners who have the necessary knowledge of the nature of disability from which the appellant or appellants is or are suffering.

(3.) The Chairman of an Assessment Appeal Tribunal shall be selected for appointment from a list of returned soldiers who have been admitted to practise as Barristers or Solicitors of the High Court or of the Supreme Court of a State, submitted in the manner provided by sub-section (4.) of section fifty-five of this Act.
Entitlement Appeal Tribunals and Assessment Appeal Tribunals are differently constituted and, therefore, I reply separately in respect of such tribunals.

item.label: (a)
item.para: In relation to Entitlement Appeal Tribunals, applications are not invited except in respect of the member who is selected in accordance with sub-section (4.) of section 55. A notification is inserted in the Commonwealth Gazette inviting the submission of lists in accordance with sub-section (4.) of section 55. At present there are two Entitlement Appeal Tribunals - No. 1 and No. 2.

item.label: (b)
item.para: After verification of qualifications and war service, the Minister selects the members of an Entitlement Appeal Tribunal and submits them to the Governor-General for appointment. The present No. 1 Entitlement Appeal Tribunal was, in June, 1948, appointed for a period of five years from the 1st July, 1948, on the recommendation of the then Minister for Repatriation. In June, 1953, the same persons were again appointed for a period of five years from the 1st July, 1953, on the recommendation of the Minister for Repatriation. In May, 1950, another Entitlement Appeal Tribunal (No. 2) was appointed from the 1st July, 1950, to the 30th June, 1954. The Chairman appointed had previously been Chairman of an Assessment Appeal Tribunal to which he was appointed in November, 1944, by the then Minister for Repatriation. One other member was appointed who previously had been appointed a member of an Entitlement Appeal Tribunal on the recommendation of the previous Minister for Repatriation. The third member was selected from lists submitted in accordance with sub-section (4.) of section 55 of the act.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The Minister makes his own recommendation after considering all the evidence he can obtain.

quote.para: Regarding the appointment of a Chairman of an Assessment Appeal Tribunal, the Minister must appoint a person from a list submitted in accordance with sub-section (3.) of section65 of the act. In relation to Assessment Appeal Tribunals the answers to the honorable member's questions are: -

item.label: (a)
item.para: The name of the person appointed must be contained in a list submitted to the Minister by any organization representing returned soldiers throughout the Commonwealth. There are at present five Assessment Appeal Tribunals - Numbers 2, 4, 5, 6 and 7. The present Chairman of No. 2 Assessment Appeal Tribunal was first appointed in February, 1947. The Chairman of No. 4 Tribunal was first appointed in May, 1945, and the Chairman of No. 5 Tribunal was first appointed in July, 1947, each by the then Minister for Repatriation. The present Minister has from time to time, reappointed these gentlemen. The Chairmen of Numbers6 and 7 Tribunals, which were created since the year 1950. have been appointed by the Minister.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The Repatriation Department checks the legal qualifications and war service of all persons included in the lists submitted by returned soldier organizations and then return them to the Minister.

item.label: (c)
item.para: After considering the qualifications and war service of all the persons whosenames appear in the lists the Minister appoints the person he considers the most fitted for the the appointment.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

item.para: Has he received a request from the Government of Western Australia for assistance for the Blackwood Flax Co-operative to enable it to continue operating after the sudden drop in the prices obtainable for its flax fibre output?
Has the Commonwealth agreed to meet losses incurred by the Commonwealth-controlled flax mills arising from the same cause?

Was the Australian flax fibre price decided by the Flax Production Committee a departmental committee, to meet competition from overseas fibre, without making any recommendation or request to the Government to restrict the importation of cheap flax fibre?
Has the Government changed its views on the need to preserve the Australian flax industry for defence reasons?

Is it intended that Government-controlled flax mills alone shall operate, sustained if necessary by subsidy, and that the only flux mill in Australia operated by private enterprise if unable to operate without subsidy will close down?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable members questions are as follows: -

item.para: Yes.

The Flax Production Committee has been authorized to meet spinners day by day consumption requirements of fibre at prices comparable to imported fibre. The committee as a trading concern has to meet any losses so incurred from its accumulated profits. As sponsor of the committee the Commonwealth Government would, of course, have to meet any net loss that was suffered over the long term. However, the Tariff Board has been requested to inquire as a matter of urgency whether assistance should be given the production in Australia of flax fibre and if so the manner and extent of such assistance. The present arrangements, therefore, can be regarded as interim only pending the outcome of the Tariff Board inquiry.

Both the Treasurer and the Minister for Commerce and Agriculture concurred in the present arrangements. It is not Government policy to use import restrictions to protect Australian industries. Their purpose is to conserve our overseas exchange. Nevertheless the import licensing branch of the Department of Trade and Customshas been kept informed of the full facts.

No. The Government will review developments in the industry when the findings of the Tariff Board are available to it. The chairman of the Flax Production Committee is at present making urgent inquiries overseas concerning government policies for the development and protection of the Max industry. The results of these inquiries will be made available to the Tariff Board as part of theFlax Production Committee's evidence.

The question of assistance to the industry will be determined in the light of the Tariff Board report. If as a result of its consideration of that report the Government extended further assistance to the industry, for example by way of tariff protection or subsidy, such assistance would not be restricted to any one section of the industry.

talk.start.para: - On the 18th November, the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) asked the following question: -

quote.para: I preface my question, which is addressed to the Prime Minister, by stating that some time ago an announcement was made that moneys received from the sale of Japanese assets in this country would be distributed amongst Australian ex-prisoners of war. As it is almost twelve months since the first payment was made, and as the payment was stated to be a first payment to the Australian ex-prisonors of war, will the Prime Minister say when the next payment is likely to be made?

question.para: I promised the honorable member a precise statement on the subject and I am now able to inform him as follows: -

quote.para: When the Trading with the Enemy Act was amended to enable effect to be given to the Government's decision to distribute the proceeds of the sale of Japanese assets amongst prisoners of war of the Japanese, the realization of Japanese assets in Australia proceeded. This disposal of all the assets has not yet been completed.

In order that former prisoners of war of the Japanese would not be prejudiced by the long delay involved in the sale of Japanese assets, the Government advanced from Consolidated Revenue the amount necessary to pay all former prisoners of war of the Japanese the sum of £32 a head. Naturally reimbursement of the amount involved will be made to Consolidated Revenue as, and when, moneys become available from the realization of Japanese assets.

The amount of £32 a head was calculated on the estimated realization value of the Japanese assets and it is most unlikely that there will be any excess available for a further distribution from this source.

When I made the statement about the distribution of the proceeds of the sale of Japanese assets in Australia, I indicated that the amount of £32 was an initial payment Any further payment, however, would be made out of the funds received from the International Committee of the Red Cross. These funds would be derived mainly from the sale of Japanese assets in neutral countries in accordance with the terms of the peace treaty with Japan. The Government has been pressing for some finality on the question of Japanese assets in neutral countries, but the problem is an extremely complex one and up to date no funds are available for distribution from this source. At present I am unable to give any indication of the likely amount of those funds or when they will be available.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister acting for the Minister for Trade and Customs, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that when post-war Japanese licences wore first issued, several substantial legitimate trade organizations were refused quotas or allocations for both toys and porcelain ware; if so, what were the reasons?

question.para: The Minister acting for the Minister for Trade and Customs has supplied the following information: -

item.para: As toys and porcelain ware had not been imported from Japan since pre-war days, licences were issued in the first place to importers who had established import quotas based on their imports of toys and porcelain ware from all sources during the base year 1950-51. It was subsequently learned that some Australian firms who had imported these goods before the war and firms who had established branch offices in Japan prior to the 1st July, 1953 (the date of the first quarter for which applications were accepted for licences to import the goods under notice from Japan) did not hold quotas, and import licences are mow being issued as follows: -
To importers holding import quotas for the same goods based on their imports fromall sources in the postwar base period.
To importers who had imported toys and porcelain ware from Japan before the war but had not imported from other sources during the base year 1950-51.
To importers who had established a branch office in Japan prior to the 1st July, 1953 and who are not included in (1) and (2).

See answer to 1.

Licensees need not necessarily have direct con tacts in Japan. In allocating licences on the basis referred to in 1 firms which were not previously importers from Japan are eligible to receive licences.
I am not aware that licensees are seeking to sell licences. However, I shall be glad to have investigations made if the honorable member will furnish me with specific instances.
It is not the practice to disclose particulars of individual licences issued as this information is confidential as between the department and each licensee.
See answer to 6.
The department has no knowledge of the disclosure of the list of licensees to any persons outside the department. Such action would be contrary to departmental procedure.
It is considered that it would be inappropriate to base the issue of licences solely on a pattern of import trade from Japan established at least thirteen years ago.

item.para: Are plans being prepared for the erection of a power station in Adelaide to operate on atomic power; if so, when is it anticipated that work will commence on this project?
Is it a fact that the total energy available from known Australian uranium supplies is greater than that available from coal supplies in Australia?
Even with the development of uranium supplies, is it anticipated that Australia will still be in a position to require all available coal supplies within Australia?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: No. The Atomic Energy Commission is doing preliminary work towards the development of design studies for a power station to be constructed some years ahead but it has not at this stage been decided where the station will be, though consideration will undoubtedly be given to the argument for placing it in South Australia. The station will however, not in any casebe in Adelaide as factors associated with atomic power plants make it undesirable that they should be located near populated areas.

The amount of energy available from known Australian supplies of uranium is considerably less than that available from known supplies of coal but this comparison is based onthe proven supplies of the uranium. There are good prospects that the supplies of uranium may be greater than have so far been proven but it is of course impossible to forecast what effects as yet unproven supplies may have on the position.

So far as can be seen at present it will be many years before power from uranium will have any effect on the demand for coal and it may never have any. The total demand for energy is likely to expand so rapidly that all the energy which can be produced from both sources will probably be required.
